awd_titl_txt: Collaborative: INFEWS: U.S.-China: Synergistic Effects of Petroleum Production and Ocean Environmental Changes on Oyster Health
awd_abstract_narration:
This project was awarded through the "National Science Foundation (NSF) / National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC) Joint Research on Environmental Sustainability Challenges" opportunity. Understanding the connections between interrelated food, energy, and water (FEW) systems is essential for the development of sustainable worldwide seafood production. Fish and shellfish serve as an important source of high-quality protein and non-saturated fat. Near-shore aquaculture supplies over 50% of global seafood production. However, over the past decades, seafood species and the production of these species have been severely affected by water contamination as a result of energy production and climate change. In this study, investigators from Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi, Louisiana State University, and Dalian Ocean University in China will identify potential risks of oyster production systems exposed to the contamination of petroleum products and the adverse environmental factors of UV radiation, ocean salinity fluctuation, and ocean acidification. An ocean model containing simulated environmental stresses will be developed to predict how petroleum products impact the development and growth of oysters in near-shore habitats in the Gulf of Mexico (GoM) and in Bohai Bay (BhB), China.  Data generated from this investigation could support the Food Safety Modernization Act goals of risk-ranking consumable seafood.

This study aims to address the two themes proposed in the National Science Foundation/National Natural Science Foundation of China Joint Research on Environmental Sustainability Challenges; 1) quantitative and computational modeling of a FEW system and 2) innovative human and technological solutions to critical FEW systems problems. The project uses the oyster as a model aquaculture species to assess the toxicity changes of crude oil compounds in response to environmental stresses. With the increasing activities in the petroleum industry along coastal lines, the accumulation of oil pollutants in oysters becomes a concern for human health.  The locations to be studied in this project, the GoM in the US and the BhB in China, share the common characteristics of robust seafood harvesting in conjunction with a vigorous petroleum production industry. However, these marine environments have distinct differences due to their geographic locations. Hence, the two unique systems represent diversified FEW networks. This diversity of the networks is expected to be explored by the computational modeling approach developed in this study. The strategies and methods employed can be further extended to other marine aquaculture species. Moreover, this investigation on the marine impact of crude oil can translate to other marine contaminants such as pesticides and pharmaceutical products, which have also become of concern in onshore/offshore aquaculture. Research results will provide 1) a better understanding of the toxicological alterations of petroleum products under global environmental change; 2) the impacts of the modification in petroleum products on the health of aquaculture species; 3) identification of environmental stress modified petrogenic products and their toxicities to oysters that should serve as references for the management of onshore/offshore aquaculture and oil production; and 4) prediction of impacts of oil production on global ocean environments and world aquaculture concurrent with climate change.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Providing essential sources of high-quality protein and unsaturated fats, near-shore fish and shellfish aquaculture account for over 50% of global seafood production. With environmental change and increasing water pollution in the coastal areas, seafood species and production have been significantly impacted in recent decades. Understanding the interconnection of food, energy, and water (FEW) systems is crucial for advancing sustainable global seafood production.

Supported by the U.S. - China Joint Research Program on Environmental Sustainability Challenges, researchers from Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi, Louisiana State University, and Dalian Ocean University in China teamed up to evaluate the risks posed to oyster production systems by petroleum contamination and environmental stressors such as UV radiation, salinity fluctuations, and ocean acidification. To achieve this goal, the research team developed a mathematical model containing various environmental factors from the ocean to predict the effects of petroleum pollutants on oyster development and growth in near-shore habitats of the Gulf of Mexico (GoM) and Bohai Bay (BhB) in China. Subsequently, the team created various environmental conditions in the lab to simulate the natural exposure of environmental petrogenic products and understand the modifications of these chemicals by environmental stress. The alteration of chemical toxicities was evaluated with a common economical shellfish species, the eastern oyster.

The team first characterized the structural and chemical changes of some major petrogenic pollutants, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), under the stress of photo exposure and salinity fluctuation. These two factors have been considered most relevant to climate change in the GoM and BhB. PAH candidates, such as anthracene, naphthalene, and pyrene, were found unstable with increasing amounts of photo exposure. The salinity also contributed to the degradation of these chemicals. As a result, many intermediate products during the photodegradation were generated and distributed into the water. These products last various amounts of time in the environment. To assess the toxicity changes of these chemicals under environmental stress, this project used the eastern oysters at different developmental stages as aquaculture species models. PAH chemicals, such as anthracene and pyrene, showed enhanced toxicities with the photodegradation indicating that intermediate products during the degradation could cause more damage than the original chemicals. Using simulated environmental stressors from an ocean model, the research team successfully identified “hot spots” of petrogenic product modifications and associated responses from oysters in a realistic environment, as proposed. A fully coupled physical-biogeochemical simulation for the year 2021 was completed. This included critical environmental variables such as salinity, temperature, nutrients, and carbonate chemistry. The model output is made publicly accessible on an open-source data server with a sharable digital object identifier (DOI). Based on the threshold salinity proposed generated from this study, the team identified several PAH hotspots through this study.

The findings of this project were disseminated at several national conferences and workshops, including the Society of Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry (SETAC) North America Annual Meetings, American Geophysical Union (AGU) Annual Meetings, and AGU Ocean Sciences. Several papers were published in peer-reviewed scientific journals. Research projects for three PhD students were supported by this grant. Two of them successfully obtained their Ph.D. degree in 2024. In addition, many undergraduate students including several underrepresented students with Hispanic backgrounds had opportunities to get training in related research areas through this project. The results of this study, as described in the proposal, provided critical information for understanding the impacts of environmental change on marine pollutants and the consequences in fisheries and aquaculture. Combining with the environmental stressor simulation model, the long-term influence of the FEW system initiated by climate change can be used as a reference for the management of onshore/offshore aquaculture and oil production, and to predict the future impacts of oil production on global ocean environments and seafood production in different counties and regions.
